text: [Music]
Hello, I'm Tim Wilcox with BBC World
News. Our top
stories. Protests on the streets of
Koala Lumpa go into a second day as the
demands for the resignation of Malaysian
Prime Minister build.
[Music]
Hello and welcome to the program. The
streets of Malaysia's capital have again
turned yellow as huge crowds in their
distinctive shirts returned to large
parts of Pala Lumpa. They're calling for
the resignation of the Prime Minister
Najib Razak over a financial scandal.
While many protesters camped out
overnight after a first day of rallies,
crowds were demanding to know why $700
million was paid into Mr. Najib's bank
account. Well, our correspondent
Jennifer Pack joins us from the
Malaysian capital. Significant numbers
there. Uh what is the sort of estimate
of the numbers on the streets?
Uh well, of course, it's been coming and
going, but certainly tens of thousands
here, although organizers put the total
participation up to 300,000 for the last
two days. The police significantly less,
saying, maybe about 30,000. But just
take a look behind me at the energy that
is flowing through this crowd. They've
been here praying, singing, uh giving
political speeches, taking pictures.
They're having a lot of fun. But of
course, they are directing their anger
towards one man, Prime Minister Naji
Brazak. He's been accused of mismanaging
a state fund called 1MDB and more
importantly also accused of taking
public money. Now he's been cleared by
the anti-corruption agency of any
wrongdoing of any of these protesters
still believe that he has done something
terribly
wrong. Our prime minister had a lot of
accusation to answer the one Malaysia DB
the 2.6 billion. Where's the answer? We
want the answer. We need a clean
government. The leaders of our nation
they never like they don't want to
answer or something that some excuses
that they gave us is like so stupid
answer what kind of donation billion
billion US dollar in your bank account
and then you say that it's donation what
kind of what kind of answer is that oh
my god you think your Malaysia citizen
are stupid no a lot of people are saying
this is a waste of
I think if you look at the number of
people who are here who left their work
today, I think they left everything they
else they can do this weekend. They are
here because they think they can make a
difference. I think we showing that the
people do have a huge power. We might
not make a change tomorrow, but this is
a start to show that we are headed
somewhere.
Well, you hear from the protesters even
if no change comes immediately, they are
not going to be disheartened simply
because this is a country that has been
ruled by a governing coalition for
almost six decades. These people want to
send a message to the government that
they cannot take their vote for granted.
How long though will the prime minister
and the authorities put up with a
demonstration like this if it were to go
into another day? I mean they didn't
want the demonstration to take place and
there's a significant security presence
there as well isn't there?
Uh yes of course the police have deemed
this rally as illegal but as of yet we
haven't seen at least here in Koala
Lumpur on Independence Square. They
blocked off of the area for rehearsals
for Independence Day, but they haven't
really moved against protesters because
they said they have respected the
barriers that were set up by the police.
And so far, everything seems to be
peaceful between the two sides. Now, the
protesters have said that they are only
going to hold it over the weekend. They
will be out of here when uh it comes to
tomorrow when the country celebrates
Independence Day. So, it seems as if
organizers are going to keep to their
word and people are fine with that. But
again, the important thing is that they
wanted to register their anger towards
the government because in recent weeks,
the prime minister has actually moved
against his critics. He's shut down
media that has been following the cases
too closely. He has sacked his deputy
for questioning his handling of this
scandal. And he has also replaced the
attorney general investigating uh into
the funds that had gone into his bank
account. So there is a lot of uh there's
a suspicion here that Prime Minister
Najib is not going to reveal the truth
of where this money has gone to uh and
is not willing to give any more answers.
So Malaysians here want to register
their voice to the governing coalition
that this is not good enough. Okay,
gentlemen in thank you very much
indeed. And uh for more on this story
and the ins and outs of the donations
controversy uh go to the website
bbc.com/news. Uh you can keep right up
to date with the latest developments and
watch Jennifer's latest reports and
follow all the tweets and blogs from our
